body:
These are jsonpath operators. They are defined in the docs in table 9.45

Table 9.45. Additional jsonb Operators

Operator | Right Operand Type | Description | Example
-- | -- | -- | --
@? | jsonpath | Does JSON path return any item for the specified JSON value? | '{"a":[1,2,3,4,5]}'::jsonb @? '$.a[*] ? (@ > 2)'
@@ | jsonpath | Returns the result of JSON path predicate check for the specified JSON value. Only the first item of the result is taken into account. If the result is not Boolean, then null is returned. | '{"a":[1,2,3,4,5]}'::jsonb @@ '$.a[*] > 2'


There is a note a bit down the page that hints at potential names, as they seem to be shorthand for corollary functions with some presets :

> Note
> The jsonb_path_exists, jsonb_path_match, jsonb_path_query, jsonb_path_query_array, and jsonb_path_query_first functions have optional vars and silent arguments.
> 
> If the vars argument is specified, it provides an object containing named variables to be substituted into a jsonpath expression.
> 
> If the silent argument is specified and has the true value, these functions suppress the same errors as the @? and @@ operators.

I'm not sure regarding the names, they seem to refer to other functions. In the v14 docs they are better defined https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/functions-json.html but they are not better defined

Re-reading my comment above, my text is not clear.

I believe `@@` and `@?` are shorthand for some of the named functions but WITH preconfigured defaults.  The operators are not named and do not behave exactly like the functions, but the functions can be passed arguments to make them behave like the operators.

Referencing the v14 docs....

---

> # jsonb @? jsonpath → boolean
> Does JSON path return any item for the specified JSON value?
> `'{"a":[1,2,3,4,5]}'::jsonb @? '$.a[*] ? (@ > 2)' → t`

is *roughly* the same as...

> # jsonb_path_exists ( target jsonb, path jsonpath [, vars jsonb [, silent boolean ]] ) → boolean
> Checks whether the JSON path returns any item for the specified JSON value. If the vars argument is specified, it must be a JSON object, and its fields provide named values to be substituted into the jsonpath expression. If the silent argument is specified and is true, the function suppresses the same errors as the @? and @@ operators do.
> `jsonb_path_exists('{"a":[1,2,3,4,5]}', '$.a[*] ? (@ >= $min && @ <= $max)', '{"min":2, "max":4}') → t

---

and...

---

> # jsonb @@ jsonpath → boolean
> Returns the result of a JSON path predicate check for the specified JSON value. Only the first item of the result is taken into account. If the result is not Boolean, then NULL is returned.
> `'{"a":[1,2,3,4,5]}'::jsonb @@ '$.a[*] > 2' → t`

is *roughly* the same as...

> # jsonb_path_match ( target jsonb, path jsonpath [, vars jsonb [, silent boolean ]] ) → boolean
> Returns the result of a JSON path predicate check for the specified JSON value. Only the first item of the result is taken into account. If the result is not Boolean, then NULL is returned. The optional vars and silent arguments act the same as for jsonb_path_exists.
> `jsonb_path_match('{"a":[1,2,3,4,5]}', 'exists($.a[*] ? (@ >= $min && @ <= $max))', '{"min":2, "max":4}') → t`

oh it seems so!

Found the definitions;
https://github.com/postgres/postgres/blob/0266e98c6b865246c3031bbf55cb15f330134e30/src/backend/utils/adt/jsonpath_exec.c#L377-L387
and
https://github.com/postgres/postgres/blob/0266e98c6b865246c3031bbf55cb15f330134e30/src/backend/utils/adt/jsonpath_exec.c#L309-L319

ha! i did not expect to see it officially in their code!

* `jsonb_path_exists_opr`
* `jsonb_path_match_opr`

I just noticed the definitions were similar, and recalled some other operators in postgres being shorthand versions of larger functions.
just those two operators, that's all they added?
I have not checked if there is something else missing

I went through the docs/tables and compared/searched SQLAlchemy source.

Table 9.44. json and jsonb Operators

operator | sqlalchemy | note
--- | --- | ---
`->` | `sqlalchemy.dialects.postgresql.json.visit_json_getitem_op_binary` |
`->>` | `sqlalchemy.dialects.postgresql.json.ASTEXT` |
`#>` | `sqlalchemy.dialects.postgresql.json.visit_json_path_getitem_op_binary` |
`#>>` | `sqlalchemy.dialects.postgresql.json.JSONPATH_ASTEXT` |


Table 9.45. Additional jsonb Operators

operator | sqlalchemy | note
--- | --- | ---
`@>` | `sqlalchemy.dialects.postgresql.json.CONTAINS` | 
`<@` | `sqlalchemy.dialects.postgresql.json.CONTAINED_BY` | 
`?` | `sqlalchemy.dialects.postgresql.json.HAS_KEY` | 
`?\|` | `sqlalchemy.dialects.postgresql.json.HAS_ANY` | 
`?&` | `sqlalchemy.dialects.postgresql.json.HAS_ALL` | 
`\|\|` |   | standard concat. does this exist elsewhere?
`-` |   | deletes a key. applies to: text, text array, integer.
`#-` |   | `jsonb #- text[] → jsonb` Deletes the field or array element at the specified path, where path elements can be either field keys or array indexes.
`@?` |   | `jsonb @? jsonpath → boolean`
`@@` |   | `jsonb @@ jsonpath → boolean`


So we're missing:

* `\|\|` maybe?  it's standard elsewhere
* `-` maybe?  it's standard elsewhere
* `#-`
* `@@`
* `@?`

I think I've used one of `->>` or `->`. let me check

We have both. `json_col[path]` renders `->`; `json_col[path].astext` renders `->>`.

They are handled by the default getitem of json

Any idea how this works: 

> `json_col[path]` renders `->`

I couldn't find anything in the source that could emit that.
late edit above. it's handled by the json `__getitem__`, and the `visit_json_getitem_op_binary`

ah ha!  the code has this string: `" -> "` and I was searching for `"->"` and `'->'` (no leading/trailing whitespace).

I'll recheck the source and update the table above

Updated the list above, but the 3 missing ops are:

* `#-`
* `@@`
* `@?`

I'm not sure if `-` or `\|\|` need special enablement for json; I assume not.

it seems not
```py
import sqlalchemy as sa
from sqlalchemy.dialects import postgresql

tt = sa.Table('tt', sa.MetaData(), sa.Column('col', postgresql.JSONB))

sub = tt.c.col - 'x'
concat = tt.c.col + 'x'

print(sub.compile(dialect=postgresql.dialect()))
print(concat.compile(dialect=postgresql.dialect()))
```
prints
```
tt.col - %(col_1)s
tt.col || %(col_1)s
```

issue.title: Implement missing `#-`, `@?` and `@@` Postgres' JSONB operators.

body:
**Guilherme Martins Crocetti** has proposed a fix for this issue in the **main** branch:

**Implement missing `#-`, `@?` and `@@` Postgres' JSONB operators.** https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/4336
